metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Using the Coronavirus Pandemic as an Opportunity to Address the Use of Human Milk and Breastfeeding as Lifesaving Medical Interventions

body_text.text: The world as we know it will be forever changed from the current pandemic of coronavirus 2 disease 2019 . The health care system is being challenged in the United States and 3 worldwide, and the general public is scared and concerned. Yet through all this, families will 4 continue to give birth and bring new life into the world. As health care providers, we could use 5 this current pandemic and a means to educate the public about the importance of human milk and 6 breastfeeding as lifesaving medical interventions. The purpose of this editorial is to provide 7 guidance regarding breastfeeding and COVID-19 and reaffirm why it is of paramount 8 importance to promote and protect the use of human milk and breastfeeding. La Leche League International (LLLI) further recommended that if someone who is 30 breastfeeding becomes ill, it is important not to interrupt direct breastfeeding (2020). In such as 31 case, the infant was already exposed to the virus by the mother and/or family and will benefit 32 most from continued direct breastfeeding (LLLI, 2020). Disruption of breastfeeding will increase the risk of the infant becoming ill because of the lack of immune support (LLLI, 2020). If any 34 member of the family has been exposed, the infant has been exposed. Hence, interruption of 35 breastfeeding may actually increase the risk of the infant becoming ill (LLLI, 2020) . public health crisis that we can address by changing the current care paradigm (Spatz, in press).
Health care providers should ensure that all families are making informed feeding choices, and 45 the provision of human milk and breastfeeding should be discussed at every prenatal interaction.

It is not enough to tell families that breastfeeding is "good." Breastfeeding saves lives! Families 47 should be taught about the science of human milk, how human milk improves developmental 48 outcomes and health for children in the short and long-term (Spatz, in press), and how 49 components of human milk are unique and not present in infant formula (Spatz, in press). In my 50 clinical role, I provide personalized prenatal lactation intervention to families, and they are 51 absolutely fascinated to learn about stem cells, white blood cells, antibodies, lactoferrin, human 52 milk oligosaccharides, and other ingredients and how the milk is specific and tailored for their 53 infant to ensure optimal health and developmental outcomes.

During prenatal care, health care providers also need to provide appropriate anticipatory 56 guidance and education. Emphasis should be given to the fact that the mother begins to secrete 57 milk from 16 weeks of pregnancy (Spatz, in press). The family must be empowered to support 58 the mother for the first 2 weeks after birth so that she can optimize her personal capacity to 59 produce milk (Spatz, in press). There is a critical window to effectively establish lactation to 60 ensure copious milk supply long term (Spatz, 2020). During prenatal care so much of the focus 61 is on preparing for labor and birth; however, the time spent in childbirth is short compared to the 62 recommended amount of time to breastfeed a child.

FIGREF0.text: In limited studies on women with COVID-19 and another coronavirus infection, severe acute 11 respiratory syndrome (SARS-CoV), the virus has not been detected in human milk (Centers for12 Disease Control and Prevention [CDC], 2020). Person-to-person spread is thought to occur 13 mainly via respiratory droplets from an infected person who coughs or sneezes (CDC, 2020). It 14 is unknown if COVID-19 positive mothers can transmit the virus through human milk (CDC, 15 2020).

FIGREF1.text: Considering the benefits of breastfeeding and the insignificant role of breastmilk in the 19 transmission of other respiratory viruses, the mother can continue breastfeeding, while applying 20 all the necessary precautions." If a mother has any flu like symptoms, she should wear a mask 21 when near the infant, including during breastfeeding; wash hands before and after contact; and 22 clean/disinfect all surfaces (UNICEF, 2020). If separation of the mother and infant is warranted, 23 the mother should start expressing milk immediately to establish and maintain milk supply 24 (CDC, 2020). Before expressing, the mother should practice hand hygiene (CDC, 2020). After 25 each pumping session, all parts that come into contact with human milk should be washed 26 thoroughly.
